bestBHT.bht: Resuming the interrupted discourse, the account explains the woman's flight into the wilderness. The dragon's persecution portrays the ongoing conflict between light and darkness in the visible world. Historical events, like Nero's burning of Rome, illustrate this vision, showcasing the persistent opposition faced by the church. As the dragon exhausted his accusations against the saints in heaven, his wrath turned towards the church on earth, resulting in severe persecution and suffering throughout history, including the rise of the papacy. This narrative reveals the enduring struggles endured by the church throughout its existence.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Resuming from the thread of the discourse, which had been interrupted by the episode...
...the ground of the corresponding conflict between light and darkness in the visible world.
...accounts for her flight into the wilderness.
Albert Barnes: When Satan saw that he was doomed to discomfiture and overthrow, as if he had been cast out of heaven...he 'persecuted the woman,' and was more violently enraged against the church on earth.
The child is represented as safe; that is, the ultimate progress and extension of the church was certain.

After the pagan persecutions ceased, and Christianity was firmly established in the empire...his enmity was vented in another form - in the rise of the papacy, and in the persecutions under that...opposition to spiritual religion no less determined and deadly than what had been waged by paganism.
Archibald T. Robertson: He persecuted (εδιωξεν). First aorist active participle of διωκω, to pursue, to chase, hostile pursuit here as in Matthew 5:10; Matthew 10:23, etc.
John now, after the 'voice' in Revelation 12:10-13, returns to the narrative in verse Revelation 12:9.
Perhaps events since A.D. 64 (burning of Rome by Nero) amply illustrated this vision, and they still do so.
John Gill: He was enraged at the church, and pursued her with great wrath, who had brought forth a Christian emperor, by whom the kingdom of Christ was encouraged and supported in the empire.
But inasmuch as the Arian persecution was the first after the fall of Paganism, and the principal one before the rise of antichrist, this may most reasonably be concluded to be meant here.
These were Christian emperors in name, but they exercised all the cruelties of the Heathen ones, if they did not exceed them; and a greater regard was shown to Paganism than to the orthodox religion.
John Wesley: And when the dragon saw — That be could no longer accuse the saints in heaven, he turned his wrath to do all possible mischief on earth."

He persecuted the woman — The ancient persecutions of the church were mentioned, Revelation 1:9; 2:10; 7:14; but this persecution came after her flight, verse6, Revelation 12:6 just at the beginning of the third woe."
These, and all the accounts of those times, show with what fury the dragon then persecuted the woman.

bhtAttempts.bht: Resuming from the thread of the discourse, which had been interrupted by the episode, the verse in Revelation 12:13 accounts for the woman's flight into the wilderness. The dragon, enraged and persecuting the woman, reveals the ongoing conflict between light and darkness in the visible world. This persecution, characterized by hostility and pursuit, not only reflects the historical events after A.D. 64, with the burning of Rome by Nero, but also illustrates the relentless opposition faced by the church throughout history, including the rise of the papacy. As the dragon saw his accusations against the saints in heaven come to an end, his wrath was turned towards the church on earth, leading to great persecution and suffering.
